content.title: Takayasu Arteritis
content.summary: Takayasu arteritis is a large-vessel vasculitis primarily affecting the aorta and its major branches. It predominantly occurs in young women and can cause stenosis, occlusion, or aneurysm formation, leading to limb claudication, renovascular hypertension, or cerebrovascular symptoms.
content.definition: A chronic granulomatous vasculitis of large arteries, primarily the aorta and its major branches, characterized by inflammatory cell infiltration and intimal hyperplasia leading to stenosis, occlusion, or aneurysm formation

epidemiology.incidence: 1-3 per million in North America; higher in Asia

pathophysiology.target: Media and adventitia of aorta and branches

systemic_symptoms.frequency: Often absent or resolved by diagnosis

vascular_symptoms.hypertension: Renovascular hypertension from renal artery stenosis

physical_findings.blood_pressure: Discrepancy between arms; often difficult to measure

Numano_classification.type_IIb: Type IIa plus thoracic descending aorta
Numano_classification.type_III: Thoracic descending, abdominal aorta, renal arteries
Numano_classification.type_IV: Abdominal aorta and/or renal arteries only
Numano_classification.type_V: Combined features of IIb and IV (entire aorta)

laboratory.ESR_CRP: Elevated in active phase, may be normal in burnt-out disease

PET_CT.findings: FDG uptake in vessel wall indicates active inflammation

conventional_angiography.role: Gold standard for detail; rarely needed for diagnosis

biologics.tocilizumab: IL-6 inhibitor; FDA approved for Takayasu

revascularization.timing: Best during quiescent phase (disease control first)

endovascular.balloon_angioplasty: May be considered for focal stenoses
endovascular.stenting: Higher restenosis rate than other vascular diseases

revascularization.outcomes: Higher restenosis in Takayasu; disease control critical

prognosis.survival: Generally good with treatment (80-90% at 10 years)

definition.@value: Large-vessel granulomatous vasculitis affecting the aorta and major branches, primarily in young women

learning_objectives: Describe epidemiology and pathophysiology of Takayasu arteritis
Classify disease extent using Numano classification
Identify timing and approach for revascularization
clinical_pearls: Young woman with pulse deficits and BP discrepancy = think Takayasu
ESR/CRP may be normal in burnt-out disease
PET-CT best for assessing disease activity
Revascularize during quiescent phase for best outcomes
Tocilizumab (IL-6 inhibitor) now FDA approved for Takayasu
